title-group.article-title: The Collective Memory of Auschwitz and World War II among Catholics in Poland:A Qualitative Study of Three Communities

abstract.p: This article discusses the results of focus group interviews with members of three different Catholic communities in Poland: the Radio Maryja Family from Rzeszów, epitomizing the so-called “Closed Church,” the intellectuals from Lublin associated with the late Archbishop Życiński, who exemplify adherents to the “Open Church,” and the Club of Catholic Intelligentsia from Kraków, which adopts a middle position between these two groups. The analysis reveals that although the groups constitute varying “communities of memory” with different perceptions of the Polish national past and relations between Poles and Jews, there are no significant differences in their memory of Auschwitz. The qualitative study of these three Catholic communities confirms the results of surveys which show that over the past years in Poland the Jewish meaning of Auschwitz has gained precedence over the Polish and Catholic meanings.

After Jewish organizations in America, Israel and Western Europe found out about the convent, they staged protests in and outside Poland in 1985–93. The Jewish protests caused counter-protests by Catholics in Poland but also prompted a Catholic-Jewish and Polish-Jewish dialogue, which consisted of meetings between Catholic and Jewish leaders in 1986–87 and a series of publications in Poland. In the course of these meetings, the Catholic Church and the Jewish organizations reached an agreement that the nuns would move to another building to be erected in the town of Oświęcim, but further away from the former camp. When, the nuns did not move to the new building, the protests of both sides continued. The controversy ended when Pope John Paul II ordered the nuns to leave the contested building. See Władysław T. In 1984 and 1985 a group of Polish scouts helping to clean up the grounds of the former camp erected crosses (and Stars of David) to commemorate the camp's victims on the field in the former Auschwitz II Birkenau camp where the ashes from the crematoria had been disposed of. The cross that had been erected for the Holy Mass said by Pope John Paul II on the site of the former Birkenau camp during his first visit to Poland in 1979 was placed at the gravel pit by the convent building at the height of the convent controversy in 1989.

In 1996, Eli Wiesel, speaking in Poland at the official commemorations of the Kielce pogrom, urged the Polish authorities to remove the “Christian/Catholic symbols” from the former Auschwitz camp. The crosses (and Stars of David) were removed from the “field of ashes” in 1997. In 1998, after a representative of the Polish government announced that the “papal cross” would also be removed, the ultra-Catholic activist K. Świtoń called for its “defense.” In 1998–99 over 300 crosses were planted around the “papal cross” by Catholics from all around the country. In 1999 these crosses were removed by the authorities. Kucia ,“The Meanings of Auschwitz in Poland.”The quantitative results on the memory of Auschwitz referred to in this article come from the surveys of representative samples of Poland's population above the age of 18, conducted on January 13–16, 1995 (N = 1,011), and February 8–12, 1996 (N = 1,200), and of those above the age of 15, conducted on January 15–17, 2000 (N = 1,008), and January 7–10, 2010 (N = 1,001). The maximal statistical measurement error in this kind of survey is +/− 3 percent for the estimate of 95 percent.

The 1995 data come fromCBOS, Oświęcim w zbiorowej pamięci Polaków (Oświęcim in the collective memory of the Poles) (,1995). The 1996, 2000 and 2010 data are Marek Kucia's. In order to ensure comparability, we refer only to the results for respondents above the age of 18 in the 2000 and 2010 surveys (N = 950 and N = 984 respectively). In the surveys, the categories “Jews” and “Poles” were used in the same way as in the contemporary historiography of and public discourse on Auschwitz.

Of all the controversies around Auschwitz, only the conflicts over the so-called “supermarket” and “disco” were not Jewish-Catholic as they concerned secular issues.

“The German invasion [of Poland] of September 1, 1939” has always been and still is considered by Poles, officially and privately, as the event that marked the beginning of World War II. The surveys show that it is by far the most remembered event of the war (see Kucia, “The Meanings of Auschwitz in Poland”). “The Soviet invasion [of Poland] of September 17, 1939”—which could not be part of Polish official memory under communism—has gained prominence in public discourse since 1989. “Auschwitz” (or “Oświęcim”) has always featured highly in Polish official and private memory of the war. The surveys show that it is the second most remembered event of the war (ibid.). “Katyń,” i.e. the massacre of about 22,000 Polish nationals, mostly army and police officers held in Soviet captivity, perpetrated by the Soviet security police (NKVD) in 1940 near the village of Katyń and elsewhere, was absent from Polish official memory until 1989, after which it not only became prominent but also became the symbol of Polish martyrdom during the war (at the hands of the Soviets)—an alternative or supplementary symbol to Auschwitz, whose “Jewishness” was becoming increasingly publicized and recognized. “The Battle of Lenino”—the first battle fought in 1943 by the communist-led Polish People's Army together with the Red Army—was a widely celebrated event in communist Poland and has become (almost) forgotten since 1989. “The Battle of Monte Cassino”—a victorious and bloody battle fought by the Polish army in Italy in 1944—was part of semi-official and private memory during communism.
